pros: Easy going, not too much work to do, low expectation.
cons: University is not honest on green card policy. If you are a foreign worker, DO NOT work there no matter what they told you at the beginning. They just DO NOT want you to get green card as they are afraid of losing you. They only want to take advantage of you as much as possible and lie to you about the non-existing green card policy. After they use up your 6-year H-1B they just kick you out, say sorry and blame the government on immigration policy - if you haven't gotten an industry H-1B (cap-subject H-1B) then you are screwed up because you cannot just get another job if you haven't been counted towards the annual quota. Luckily I finally got one this year (but still wasted more than TWO YEARS getting it due to their lies), so I left right after the cap-subject H-1B has been approved, giving them only one week notice - I should have just given one day notice as what they have done to me was indeed ridiculous and disgusting. How could a university be successful when they think $300 lawyer fee is way more important than their employees' carrer? They sold their souls to devil for only $300.

pros: Lafayette is a nice city to enjoy the Cajun culture. Campus organizations are awesome.
cons:
Graduate study (Ph.D.) in the Department of Chemical Engineering comes with lots of coursework (16 courses) with very low pay and impossible expectation of publishing 3 papers and one NSF proposal writing with no resources (Negative work-life balance). The department is filled with instructors and assistant professors with zero graduate student management skills. The biggest irony is, the department has 100% Ph.D. student dropout in the last couple of years (no Ph.D. in Chemical Engineering was offered). Yet the Department Head claims that their program is the best. The department will provide one room for 5-6 MS or Ph.D. students (very congested and not suitable for research work). 
Due to excess favoritism, the Department of Chemical Engineering will hire an instructor with a Bachelor’s degree (look on the department website). Gossiping and jealousy are common.

pros: The city is 2014 Happiest Place in the US.  The city has one of the lowest rates of unemployment in 2013.  The area has great food, great music, and beautiful bayous.
cons: The culture of the community, area, and government leadership doesn't support education; instead raiding education funds to divert to other interests.  This leaves the University talent rich and incentive poor.  It is difficult to recruit new talent and they are bleeding the existing talent.

pros: We are the Ragin Cajuns.  The athletic teams are improving. Coffee shop in the library and bookstore.  Online learning is starting to take off.
cons: Computer system is slowly crawling out of the dark ages.  Management takes too long on decisions and keeps hiring the wrong people, which causes problems for everyone else.  Salaries have been frozen for over 5 years, unless your division head is smart enough to restructure and give out new titles to get a pay raise.

pros: Freedom is rewarding. Never been discouraged to try something new or different.  When permitted, merit raises are given. Technology use in the classroom is encouraged.
cons: No encouragement for good performance. Non-existent mentorship or on the job training. Be prepared to learn the ropes on your own. Archaic internal procedures. Terrible benefits. Who doesn't offer dental these days? Views faculty and staff as inhuman commodities. No pride in campus appearance. Buildings and lawns in disrepair.

pros: Medium size school with unique identity and spirit. If you are looking for a place that offers festivals, this is it. Great local food. Humble students with great family values.
cons: Extremely poor support to higher education, and to faculty members. No funding for conference travel, no startup funds. Consider yourself lucky to receive an office and a used computer. Building for liberal arts needs plenty of updates and is full of asbestos. Heavy teaching loads and technology available only in a few classrooms. A good place to stay for three years to get experience, but definitely not the place to get tenured.

pros: The campus is very nice and small town location provides for a family oriented environment. University schedules are great, allowing a lot of time off. I guess satisfaction depends on the department you work in and your colleagues.
cons: Campus meal selection is not all that great. Some buildings are a bit run down, but renovations are always going on. Parking can be a nuisance.

pros: The best resdon to work at UL is that they sdapt to your schedule. They also understand that you are a student so they only require 10 hours a week which is pretty good.
cons: They obly pay minimum wage for jobs such as academic coach. Sometimes the 10 hours can be too little and they always hire financial aid kids before anyone else.

review_title: MEPOL is an OK place to work for a year or two.  But any longer and you're sliding backward professionally.
pros:
Work with a multitude of manufacturers as a technical and business consultant.

If working in a regional office, there is much flexibility and autonomy.

There is a fair amount of training and learning that can be accomplished to grow personally and technically.

Project directors grew professionally by creating their own business opportunities (sales and marketing efforts) and by working closely with and assiting various organizations to improve and succeed.
cons:
The salary was somewhat low. 

Becuase there were a lot of grants available to fund the consulting and training performed by MEPOL employees, the empolyees lost their ability to succeed in the business world without corporate welfare programs. 

The fees charged for the work performed were low.  A combination of this and the grant funds available for clients watered down the market for said work and caused MEPOL employees not to be taken seriously.  

Management appeared to have more of a mission to continue to maintain their positions in order to meet retirement goals. Employees were expendable and readily insulted in private and around others in an unprofessional manner.

Employees were not encouraged to or allowed to suggest or implement improvement plans within the organization.  Almost all continuous improvement and growth concepts that MEPOL actually teaches to clients were disregarded and considered not applicable to the organization itself.

There in no real opportunity for upward mobility.  Job titles may change in name, but essentially, the work done today will be the same work done in 5 years with little to no increased responsibilities.  The organization is very flat.  Therefore, income potential is very limited.  

Because there is so much government grant money given to the organization, employees really cannot justify any pay increases because, even if they do an exceptional job at developing, maintaining and growing business in their regions, the organization does not really rely on the employees to make it successful. This fact may be unspoken, but it is well understood and the attitudes of management reflect it.

review_title: Great but getting paid can be troublesome
pros: Great experience working with Professors in my major.  I truly feel that I am getting qualified to go directly into any job after graduating
cons: It is not often that I get paid a month late.  Payroll only works once a month and if the forms are turned in late, the pay for that month gets push back a month.

review_title: Stable job, good people, but lots of red tape
pros: As an employee of UL Lafayette, you have a reasonable amount of job security. They don't fire anyone. You can't beat the people. There is a great community, if you want to be a part of it.
cons: It's government. This job stripped me of my desire to make things better because you get so much push back. It may be different for people in a higher position, but I doubt it.

review_title: Solid place to get an education.
pros: Solid university to get an education and work. I was a Research Assistant while getting my MS. Pay was not great but that is expected as an RA.
cons: Navigating the system was difficult at times. Bureaucracy is thick as with most universities.

pros: Great students, faculty, and environment.
